ch04-l01.question: What is the purpose of an account?
ch04-l01.answer:
An account gives PolicyCenter users the flexibility to create and manage a customer's account independent of policies with which the account may be associated. The ability to manage an account separately from a policy can be useful when assigning policy and account visibility to different types of users.

In addition, PolicyCenter utilizes the name clearance function to ensure that a person or company is not an existing account and that they are not represented by another producer for the given policy type.

ch04-l01.question: How many accounts can a policy be attached to?
ch04-l01.answer: A policy can belong to only one account.

Iwo different claims that use the same security profile can have two
¢ completely different access control lists. Why?

[a

different access control lists if they are owned by users in different groups.

Business hierarchy.

ch07-l09.question: Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?
ch07-l09.answer:
Whatis the significance of a rule set's root entity?
oY” Every rule set is tied to an entity, known as the root entity. This determines which class
of objects the rule set is tied to. It also determines the object available to the rules in

the rule set when the rule set is triggered.

ch07-l09.question:
Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
Yo first action" rule set?
ch07-l09.answer:
Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
a first action" rule set?
? In an “execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are
execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In
an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first
true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule
set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an

assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.

ch11-l04.answer:
What kind of entities are initially put into read-only bundles?
Under what circumstance would you need to copy one of those entities
: to a writable bundle and how is this done?

Entities that are the result of a query are put into read-only bundles, and entities
referenced by foreign key are put into a read-only bundle if the referencing entity is
also in a read-only bundle.

You need to copy these entities to a writable bundle if you need to modify them, which
is done via the bundle's add method.

Every destination can optionally have a request plugin, but it must have a

processed from the Message table. Without a transport plugin, messages for a given
destination would have no way of being sent to the corresponding external system.

by two (or more) similar destinations.

ch11-l15.question:
Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external

Y systems?

Seo e Soo e esses see sen
ch11-l15.answer:
Why should the send method never send a message to multiple external
Y systems?

The message acknowledgement architecture assumes that each message is sent to
only one destination. If a given send method sent a message to multiple destinations,
then there could be multiple acknowledgements, errors, or unprocessed messages,
and the messaging architecture would not be able to identify the state of the message.

amount from base and adjusted rates and then prorating that amount based on the
